content.title: Divide and Conquer Strategy
content.description: Break complex tasks into smaller, independent subtasks. Each subtask should be solvable independently. This reduces complexity and enables parallel execution where possible.
examples:
Task: Implement user authentication
Subtasks:
1. Design database schema for users
2. Implement password hashing
3. Create login endpoint
4. Create session management
5. Add logout functionality

content.title: Dependency Ordering Strategy
content.description: Order tasks based on dependencies. Complete prerequisite tasks before dependent tasks. Build a dependency graph to identify the critical path and enable proper sequencing.
examples:
1. Analyze dependencies between tasks
2. Create dependency graph
3. Identify tasks with no dependencies (start here)
4. Execute tasks in topological order
5. Verify each task completion before starting dependents

content.title: Determinism First Constraint
content.description: When planning any task, determinism must be the first consideration. Reject any plan that includes random selection, time-based branching, or non-reproducible operations.

content.title: Validate Before Execute Strategy
content.description: Always validate inputs and preconditions before executing a plan. This prevents wasted work and catches errors early. Validation should be a separate, explicit step.
examples:
1. Parse and validate input parameters
2. Check preconditions (file exists, permissions, etc.)
3. Validate configuration
4. If validation fails, return error immediately
5. If validation passes, proceed with execution

content.title: Smallest Testable Unit Heuristic
content.description: Break tasks down to the smallest unit that can be independently tested. This enables faster feedback and easier debugging. Each unit should have clear success criteria.

content.title: Phase-Based Implementation Pattern
content.description: Organize work into distinct phases with clear deliverables. Each phase builds on the previous one. This pattern enables progress tracking and provides natural checkpoints.
examples:
Phase 1: Design and specification
Phase 2: Core implementation
Phase 3: Integration
Phase 4: Testing and validation
Phase 5: Documentation
